You can use the ActionDirectory mechanism to add new URIs to a running 
crawl. However, those URIs will be treated the same as other seed or 
discovered URIs. So, discovered outlinks from those URIs will be 
followed (or not) according to the scope rules.

Some of the formats you can use in the ActionDirectory allow you to 
specify new URIs in what is essentially the 'recovery log' format -- and 
thus include your own versions of the 'hopsPath' (the string of letters 
describing the types of links that have been followed) and 'viaUri' 
(source URI from which the current URI was discovered).

If you were trying to hack together something to acheive the effect you 
describe, that might prove useful. For example, if your scope has a 
maxHopsDecideRule with a threshold of 20 hops, you could give your 
'exact URLs' fake hopsPaths of 'LLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLL' (20 navlink hops). 
Thus, any new 'L' links out of that page would be over the threshold, 
and not enqueued. (Other embedded 'transcluded' images, resources, etc. 
would be retrieved, or not, according to your other settings.)

You could possibly even put a totally fake value into hopsPath -- it's 
just a string and I don't think it's validated in current code to only 
draw from the usual LEXRP tokens -- and then write your own DecideRule 
(in Java or via ScriptedDecideRule) that treats outlinks starting from 
your custom plug value differently.

(I'm not a fan of that approach aesthetically, but it should work. It 
does suggest another more general feature, URIs which carry with them 
and pass along a 'personality' token which allows them to be treated 
differently, just as overlay settings can be different for different 
sites/URI patterns. Some future version might have that feature to 
better allow mixing many different crawl purposes in a single 'job'.)

- Gordon @ IA
